title: Political Sociology
description: Course focuses on the interaction between state and society. It discusses central concepts of political sociology (social cleavages, mobilization, the state, legitimacy), institutional characteristics, causes, and consequences of contemporary political regimes (liberal democracies, authoritarianism, communism), and processes of political change. Students cannot receive credit in this course if they have already taken SOCI 148. Prerequisites: students must apply and be accepted to the Global Seminar Program.
